item.description: Monster Cables, which makes extremely high-priced stereo cables, has apparently sent a cease-and-desist letter to Blue Jeans Cable, alleging various kinds of infringement. Bad move ‚Äì the pres‚Ä¶

item.title: New USPTO Memo Makes Fighting Patent Trolls Even Harder
item.description: The U.S. Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) just made a move that will protect bad patents at the expense of everyone else. In a memo released February 28, the USPTO further restricted access to inter partes review, or IPR‚Äîthe process Congress created to let the public challenge invalid patents...

item.title: All About Vibe Coding - Engineering Manager AMA
item.description:
It's all the rage these days and everyone from your hair stylist to your fish groomer is talking about it... Vibe coding!
What the heck is it? Who is it good for? Are the vibes immaculate? Let's find out.
As with all livestreams, I'm looking forward to answering YOUR questions! So join me live and ask in the chat, or you can comment now and I can try to get it answered while I stream.

item.title: Weekly Recap - 2025-03-21
item.description: Check out this week from Dev Leader! Here's a list including articles and videos on software engineering, career development, and programming in C#!

item.title: The little book about OS development
item.description: This text is a practical guide to writing your own x86 operating system. It is designed to give enough help with the technical details while at the same time not reveal too much with samples and code excerpts. We‚Äôve tried to collect parts of the vast (and often excellent) expanse of material and tutorials available, on the web and otherwise, and add our own insights into the problems we encountered and struggled with.

item.title: Pen and Paper Exercises in Machine Learning
item.description: This is a collection of (mostly) pen-and-paper exercises in machine learning. The exercises are on the following topics: linear algebra, optimisation, directed graphical models, undirected graphical models, expressive power of graphical models, factor graphs and message passing, inference for hidden Markov models, model-based learning (including ICA and unnormalised models), sampling and Monte-Carlo integration, and variational inference.

item.title: Options Pattern Validation in ASP.NET Core With FluentValidation
item.description: Elevate your ASP.NET Core configuration with FluentValidation integration that catches configuration errors at startup, preventing silent failures and runtime exceptions with more expressive validation rules than Data Annotations.

item.title: Matched and Deleted
item.description: The curious case of Hinge and SATC

item.title: Indefinite Backpack Travel ‚Äì Jeremy Maluf
item.description: Updated September 2024

item.title: How I force LLMs to generate correct code
item.description: Unvibe: A Python Test-Runner that generates correct code

item.title: Database Protocols Are Underwhelming
item.description: If you‚Äôve been in this trade for a while, you have probably seen dozens of debates on the merits and problems of SQL as a relational database query language. As an ORM maintainer, I have a few gripes with SQL, but overall it is workable, and anyway, it has so much inertia that there‚Äôs no point fantasizing about a replacement.

item.title: Early Thoughts on OpenAI‚Äôs ‚ÄòAgents‚Äô
item.description: ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt an agent just an LLM workflow?‚Äù. This has been true of a lot of companies building ‚Äúagents‚Äù recently. I like Anthropic‚Äôs definition, which is a program that can use tools and make its own decisions.

item.title: Use Long Options in Scripts
item.description: Many command line utilities support short form options (-f) and long form options (--force). Short form is for interactive usage. In scripts, use the long form.

item.title: Rusty string formatting in PHP
item.description: Exploring software development with PHP, JavaScript, Rust, and beyond.

item.title: "Vibe Coding" vs Reality
item.description: Reviewing the capabilities and limitations of LLM agents in software development and their impact on skilled and less skilled developers.

item.title: The Software Engineering Identity Crisis - Annie Vella
item.description: Many of us became software engineers because we found our identity in building things. Not managing things. Not overseeing things. Building things. With our own hands, our own minds, our own code. But that identity is being challenged. AI coding assistants aren‚Äôt just changing how we write software - they‚Äôre fundamentally transforming who we are. We‚Äôre shifting from creators to orchestrators, from builders to overseers. From engineers to something that looks suspiciously like‚Ä¶ managers.

item.title: I made an app for competitive hot air balloon pilots
item.description: This is a fairly long story of why I built Balloon Navigator, what‚Äôs involved to fly with centimeters level precision when you can only use wind and how technology is shaping modern ballooning today.

item.title: LLM Assisted Fuzzing
item.description: A new approach to false-positives.

item.title: Don't guessbuild
item.description: How we avoid guessbuilding at Operately by stopping feature development where certainty ends and speculation begins.

item.title: Why you shouldn't start with a mobile app
item.description: Why starting your project with a web-based MVP is often faster and more cost-effective? They simplify development, reduce costs, and enable quick iterations‚Äîwithout sacrificing quality.

item.title: How to have great taste
item.description: Taste is what differentiates the good from the great. So, how can I have better taste? This is my ongoing log of what I have learned.

item.title: A Win for Encryption: France Rejects Backdoor Mandate
item.description: In a moment of clarity after initially moving forward a deeply flawed piece of legislation, the French National Assembly has done the right thing: it rejected a dangerous proposal that would have gutted end-to-end encryption in the name of fighting drug trafficking. Despite heavy pressure from the...

item.title: GitHub - Devolutions/IronRDP: Rust implementation of the Microsoft Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP)
item.description: Rust implementation of the Microsoft Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) - Devolutions/IronRDP

item.title: 95% AI-written code? Unpacking the Y Combinator CEO‚Äôs developer jobs bombshell
item.description: Garry Tan says YC startups are launching with 95% AI-written code. What does this mean for the shape and size of engineering teams?

item.title: REST Constraint #3: Going Stateless for Scalability - Chris Woody Woodruff
item.description: When it comes to building scalable web applications, statelessness is one of REST‚Äôs most powerful constraints. It simplifies architecture, makes scaling easier, and helps APIs handle massive traffic loads without breaking a sweat. But what does being ‚Äústateless‚Äù actually mean in REST, and why is it such a big deal?

item.title: Vibe Coding is a Dangerous Fantasy
item.description: Last week, X exploded when a ‚Äúvibe coder‚Äù announced his SaaS was under attack. His business, built entirely with AI assistance and ‚Äúzero hand-written code,‚Äù was experiencing bypassed subscriptions, maxed-out API keys, and database corruption. His follow-up admission made this notable: ‚Äúas you know, I‚Äôm not technical so this is taking me longer than usual to figure out.‚Äù As someone deeply immersed in the AI code generation space, I‚Äôve been watching this unfold with a mix of sympathy and frustration. Let me be clear ‚Äî I‚Äôm not against AI-assisted development. My own tool aims to improve code generation quality. But there‚Äôs a growing and dangerous fantasy that technical knowledge is optional in the new AI-powered world. After observing many similar (though less public) security disasters, I‚Äôve come to a controversial conclusion: vibe coding isn‚Äôt just inefficient ‚Äî it‚Äôs potentially catastrophic.

item.description:

What stands out? What can be improved?
Let's check it out together!

item.title: I used AI to write tests for my .NET application... Here's what happened
item.description:
Want to master Clean Architecture? Go here: https://bit.ly/3PupkOJ Want to unlock Modular Monoliths? Go here: https://bit.ly/3SXlzSt Get the source code here: https://www.patreon.com/milanjovanovic
In this practical walkthrough, I explore how AI can transform the often tedious process of writing unit tests for .NET applications. Starting with a tour of my semi-complex .NET project, I explain its real-world use cases and demonstrate some existing test implementations. The video reveals why providing AI (specifically using Cursor) with example tests dramatically improves its ability to generate high-quality unit tests that match your coding standards and patterns. Watch as I demonstrate the complete workflow - from generating unit tests for the Domain layer to troubleshooting and fixing AI-generated code errors, and finally running the successful tests in Visual Studio.
We'll then extend the approach to the Application layer, showing how this technique can be applied across different parts of your architecture. Whether you're looking to reduce testing bottlenecks or improve your coverage, this step-by-step guide shows exactly how AI can become a valuable addition to your .NET development toolkit.
Working with LLMs in .NET using Microsoft.Extensions.AI https://www.milanjovanovic.tech/blog/working-with-llms-in-dotnet-using-microsoft-extensions-ai
Check out my courses: https://www.milanjovanovic.tech/courses
Read my Blog here: https://www.milanjovanovic.tech/blog
Join my weekly .NET newsletter: https://www.milanjovanovic.tech
Chapters 0:00 My recommendations 2:53 Cursor and .cursorrules 3:42 Domain unit testing with Cursor 7:34 Reviewing AI-generated tests 9:09 Application layer unit tests
item.author: (Milan Jovanoviƒá)
